description:
Cadophora gregata is a fungal species that belongs to the phylum Ascomycota. It is known to be a plant pathogen, primarily affecting soybean plants. The fungus is responsible for causing a disease known as brown stem rot (BSR) in soybean crops.

Cadophora gregata is a slow-growing, non-sporulating fungus that can be isolated from the vascular tissues and stems of infected soybean plants. The fungus colonizes the xylem vessels, leading to the development of characteristic brown discoloration and internal stem necrosis, which are the hallmarks of brown stem rot.

The disease caused by Cadophora gregata can result in significant yield losses in soybean production, particularly in areas with cool and wet growing conditions that favor the fungal infection. Understanding the biology and epidemiology of this pathogen is crucial for developing effective management strategies to control brown stem rot and mitigate its impact on soybean cultivation.
